For BADAPPLE promiscuity analysis.

    badapple_servlet
    Badapple = Bioactivity data associative promiscuity pattern learning engine
    Generates promiscuity scores (pScore) for input molecules, more precisely, the scaffolds contained therein, based on a database of bioactivity data.

    Static utility methods for BADAPPLE database system.

Package edu.unm.health.biocomp.badapple Description

For BADAPPLE promiscuity analysis. Utilizes HScaf package, accesses database containing compound and scaffold assay statistics to generate promiscuity scores.

BADAPPLE = Bio- Activity Data Associative Promiscuity Pattern Learning Engine

Functionality

  • Utilizes HScaf (edu.unm.health.biocomp.hscaf) package.
  • Accesses database containing compound and scaffold assay statistics.
  • Database server may be PostgreSQL or MySql.
  • Generates promiscuity scores for scaffolds and compounds.

badapple application command line help

badapple - bioactivity database associative promiscuity pattern learning engine

From the UNM Translational Informatics Division

usage: badapple [options]
  required:
    -i IFILE .................. input molecules
    or
    -out_scaf OSCAFS .......... output all scaffolds w/ scores and stats
    or
    -annotate_scaf ............ annotate all scaffolds w/ scores (write to db)
    or
    -describedb ............... test connection; describe database
    or
    -describescaf SCAFID ...... describe scaf: mols, stats
  options:
    -o OFILE .................. output molecules, w/ scores
    -dbtype DBTYPE ............ database type (postgres|mysql) [postgres]
    -dbhost DBHOST ............ database host [localhost]
    -dbport DBPORT ............ database port [5432]
    -dbname DBNAME ............ database name [openchord]
    -dbschema DBSCHEMA ........ database schema [badapple]
    -dbusr DBUSR .............. database user
    -dbpw DBPW ................ database password
    -maxatoms MAX ............. max atom count of input mol [100]
    -maxrings MAX ............. max ring count of input mol [10]
    -nmax NMAX ................ quit after NMAX molecules
    -nskip NSKIP .............. skip NSKIP molecules
    -v ........................ verbose
    -vv ....................... very verbose
    -vvv or -debug ............ very very verbose (slows process)
    -h ........................ this help

Known bugs, issues

  • Scaffold analysis must be consistent at client and in database. If client dissects input query molecule into scaffolds, these must match exactly the scaffolds stored in the database. If scaffold analysis implementations comply strictly with the HScaf algorithm, different toolkits and/or versions can be used. An alternate approach is to rely on a database function for scaffold analysis. A prior implementation used ChemAxon SMARTS to store scaffolds as queries in a JChem-cartridge Oracle database.
  • Apart from the scaffold analysis is the efficient and rigorous indexing of scaffolds via canonical smiles. As with compound databases, it cannot be assumed that two implementations (toolkit or version) result in the same canonical smiles. However, the client toolkit normally does not need to canonicalize a query, which can be done via database cartridge function (e.g. in OpenChord, openbabel.cansmiles()).

References

  1. See demo web app at UNM Translational Informatics Division Public Web Apps.
  2. Gcode project UNM-Biocomp-HScaf
  3. HierS: Hierarchical Scaffold Clustering, Wilkens et al., J. Med. Chem. 2005, 48, 3182-3193.
Author:
Jeremy J Yang
